results.title: Les Premiers Empires
results.brief_description:
Episode 5 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Hammourabi, king of Babylon writes the first legal code. In this world made of rival cities, visionary rulers push and battle to built vast empires. This episode follows Darius, king of Persia and his many battles to expand his empire eastward to encompass Greece and Athens. It also recounts the formidable epic of Alexander the Great who succeeded in uniting Greece and Persia under his command.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Les Conquetes de L'islam
results.brief_description:
Episode 8 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Starting with a review of the Roman Empire in year 313 (when Constantine converts to Chritianity), this episode moves on to examine an other monotheist religion: Islam. It brushes a broad stroke portrait of Mohamad and surveys the expansion of the Isalmic era of influence from India to Spain.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Les Carolingiens
results.brief_description:
Episode 9 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Overview of the Carolingians’ rise and fall, from the crowning of Charlemagne in 814 to the partition of his Empire by his three sons in 843

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Les Batisseurs de Cathedrales
results.brief_description:
Episode 11 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Following the fall of the Carolingian Empire, Europe at the beginning of Xth century lives in a climate of constant insecurity. It is in this climate that great advances in architecture are made, in particular in vaulting techniques. Other topics include: the Crusades. See also: ‘Le temps de cathedrales’ (Series #S002025)

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Les Annees Folles = the Crazy Years
results.brief_description:
Episode 25 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
This episode takes a particular interest in the development of aviation, from the first experiments by Otto Lilienthal in 1895 through to Lindbergh’s 1924 flight across the Atlantic. Other subjects include: the the 1929 Krach and the economic depression, the annexion of Austria by Hitler in 1938 as well as a survey of intellectual life in Paris in between the wars.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le Siecle des Lumieres = the Age of Reason
results.brief_description:
Episode 20 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
This European intellectual movement of the 17th and 18th centuries in which ideas concerning God, reason, nature, and man were synthesized into a worldview that gained wide assent and that instigated revolutionary developments in art, philosophy, and politics. Central to Enlightenment thought were the use and the celebration of reason, the power by which man understands the universe and improves his own condition. The goals of rational man were considered to be knowledge, freedom, and happiness. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le Siecle de Pericles
results.brief_description:
Episode 6 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
In 450 BC, Pericles lays the foundation of a democratic system in Athens. This episode examines the Golden Age of Athens with its flourishing artistic and political life. It also compares it with the model of society developped in neighbouring Sparta. Topics include: theatre, architecture, religion and Socratic philosophy.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le Siecle D'or Espagnol
results.brief_description:
Episode 15 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Though the traditional beginning of the Reconquista goes back to 718, when the Christian Asturians opposed the Moors at the Battle of Covadonga, the impulse toward reconquest was not strong during the first three centuries of Muslim hegemony. It was in the 11th century, when Moorish unity broke down and the Christian kingdoms of northern Spain began to be affected by an aggressive, anti-Muslim, crusading spirit, that the movement began in earnest. A series of wars followed, and by the mid-13th century most of the peninsula had been subjected to Christian rule, though the continued existence of a Moorish enclave around Granada in southern Spain served to keep the spirit of the Reconquista alive until the end of the 15th century. Many historians believe that subsequent Spanish emphasis on religious uniformity, evidenced by the strong influence of the Inquisition and the expulsion of people of Moorish and Jewish descent, can be traced back to this crusading struggle of the Middle Ages. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica. Other topics include: The beginning of the slave trade, the Conquistadores and prominent artists of the period, such as El Greco and Cervantes.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le Quattrocento
results.brief_description:
Episode 14 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The Quattrocento was a period of prosperity and steady progression in the arts toward the harmonious balance achieved in the High Renaissance. In concrete terms, the Quattrocento is regarded as beginning in 1401 with a competition to design the eastern doors for the Baptistery in Florence and ending in 1503 with the election of Cardinal Giuliano della Rovere as Pope Julius II. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Le printemps des peuples = The awakening of the people
results.brief_description:
Episode 23 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The awakening of the people in 1830 and more famously in 1848 was a series of republican revolts against European monarchies, beginning in Sicily and spreading to France, Germany, Italy, and the Austrian Empire. They all ended in failure and repression and were followed by widespread disillusionment among liberals. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].
